It's basically "Developer mode". It enables extra options that involve signing files and publishing updates. So if you updated a site you're working on, or manually edited your user files for a site like ZeroMe, you can sign those files with your key, authorizing them, and then you can publish your changes to the network. Obviously you can only do this with stuff you made, like comments on a site you posted on, or a blog you're making.
Zeronet or ZeroMe? Zeronet is a distributed web hosting platform where none of the sites are stored on central servers. ZeroMe is a social network that lives on the distributed Zeronet.

That is a nightmare. I haven't used Dell in ages since they never had the specs I needed in my price range, so I had two HP laptops. First one was a gift, second one I bought myself. Funny enough, both had the same issue of the hinge breaking and the screen starting to fail, despite being completely different models built years apart from each other. It happened to the second one even faster than it did the first. Throwing numerous other small issues I had with both into the mix, and I've sworn off ever buying another HP laptop again.

I'm now using a Lenovo y50-70. I've had zero issues with the hardware besides the slow SSHD that it shipped with, but that has since been replaced by a 1TB SSD. Other than that it's worked great, except for the fact that I'm stuck using Windows on it because of the graphics software I need to use :P  So I haven't tried installing Linux on it myself, but from what I've read of others experience people have gotten distros like Ubuntu working fine.

Protip: For quotes you do this -

```
>This is a quote
```

>This is a quote
Unfortunately it's mostly manual. I use WinMerge to scan for changes every once in a while and then I'll merge what I need.

@ExeciN: That doesn't work very well if you modified code. For example, blindly merging `all.js` or `all.css` with an updated version could cause things to break if you made a decent amount of changes. Writing a script that would be able to account for changes you made would probably involve more work than just skimming through things real quick with WinMerge. 

Of course if the source for whatever you're cloning is available on GitHub(Like all the main Zero* sites are) you could just fork it that way and use git to help you manage merges instead.
That's a bug in Windows Guests. There's a fix for it, but I can't remember off the top of my head. I'll look for it.

How do you insert a facepalm emoji using a desktop keyboard? Asking for a friend.

1000x Yes. I especially hate it when they mandate I use a specific number of upper/lower case and symbol characters. I'm supposed to remember these, right? Length I can agree with, but forcing random things doesn't help anybody, including the security of the password. All you do by enforcing rules is make the password *less* secure. Password rules mean nothing when the password cracker can easily look them up. 

Set a minimum length. Let us use whatever character from whatever language or emoji we want. Ban the most frequently used passwords. Prevent idiots from using their names or the name of your app/service. **But for the love of security, don't give us rules.**

---
PS: Security Questions are also stupid :P

Yes and no. If they specifically state that it's only to block "malicious" ads they could get away with it, and I think that's their goal. I'm already sick of all the Javascript redirects and popups on mobile that make it literally impossible to visit sites without my adblocker on. I have no choice but to choose between getting harassed or not funding the site I'm visiting. I hate that but there's little I can do, or even what site operators can do. The best solution would be for Ad Networks to prevent javascript in the Ads they serve, but the likely hood of that happening, especially with the more "flexible" Ad Networks, is low. So the only other way would be for Browser makers to fight back, because if they don't this malicious advertising is going to keep happening.

 The motivation for Google to do this might actually be because people could be switching to other browsers with addons or built-in adblockers, especially on mobile with Chrome not supporting addons. This not only means people are ditching Google's browser, but also opting for choices that involve blocking Google's Ad network as well, despite Google doing a lot of effort in preventing these Ads on their network. Because at the rate things are going Ads in general are going to become worthless as more and more people block them, killing a primary revenue source for Google.

@ulrichard: Not really actually. The way they seem to be mainly going is not List blocking like your average Ad blocker addon does. They will be blocking specifically the way these malicious Ads work. Prevent popups, prevent unauthorized Javascript redirects, etc. Targeting type, not source, would prevent bias. Though if they do decide to punish certain sources like the article mentions off-hand, then they'd be open for antitrust and abuse. But if they stick to blocking types, then they'd be in the clear for the most part. Any legal complaints could be quelled by a good lawyer basically stating that these malicious Ads were damaging their software's reputation and endangering their business.

But anything is better than DSL with 200-1000+ms ping at 2mbps, Cable with bandwidth that dives to unusable during peak hours, or overloaded Mobile and GEO Satellite internet with tiny data caps.

You could always just manually clone ZeroUp and modify it for yourself. The filter is at row 2847 in `all.js`.
Probably I side effect of all the improvements made for Big File support.
ZeroUp requires ZeroNet v0.6.0

It is mostly a back end change, but on the user side it finally enables reliable file sharing and streaming video, which weren't practical to do on ZeroNet before. Big File support gave ZeroNet the ability to share pieces of files like Torrents do, which allows more efficient peer-to-peer sharing of data between users. Before ZeroNet had to download the entire file from a single source, which is okay for small files, but with large files it's unreliable since you have to download 100MB+ of data from a single source that may go offline at any time or have really slow upload speeds.

@Polar: Big File support is already done, besides tweaks and bug fixes. IPFS was considered and rejected because critical features were either missing or not yet implemented. Lack of TOR support was critical, and also there'd be extra overhead running the seperate IPFS daemon.
Uploading was pretty much just like seeding a new torrent, combined with the simplicity of using a file sharing site.

@Kaffie: Way better than webtorrent at this point, especially for streaming media, as files are seeded even when people don't leave a tab open, and it's easy to see what files you're seeding. Though I still give the edge to normal torrents as far as downloading files goes, since a torrent client still gives you more control over things like bandwidth, connections, file location, etc.
Talk about exploitative. That pricing model reminds me of microtransactions in video games, where you have to buy the in-game currency in bulk before you can spend a small amount of it.

From what I understand of it, P2P Livestreaming is complicated, especially if you care about the stream actually being "live". BitTorrent has been trying it off and on and seem to have finally got the tech down, but with it being proprietary and them not being able to find any customers that want to use it commercially, it's just rotting. 

Either way, not sure it's worth the development time it'd take away from ZeroNet itself right now.

Yeah, it's annoying how everything is gated and DRM protected. Music has been DRM free for years and it's doing fine. 

One interesting site I've found is **Wakanim.tv**. It's an Anime service available in a few Nordic(English subs), German(German subs), and French(French subs) regions. They have a streaming subscription, but also a purchase option. And the best part, the purchased videos can be downloaded as high-bitrate DRM free MP4 files. I was able to access them via a Swedish VPN and pay using my US Paypal(Visa and Mastercard are also accepted). You pay using credits, with 1 credit = 1 euro. What's interesting is that 1 episode is 1 credit, and a full-season (usually 13 episodes) was 10 credits, but to test it out I bought one episode and discovered that the full season price had actually gone down to 9 credits! I've never seen adaptive season pricing like that on other VOD providers. Really nice service. Just wish my Swedish VPN was faster so that I didn't have to wait an hour to download a 3GB 1080p video.
